Games enter the classroom
 
 Video games could soon be transplanted from their natural habitat to the more academic atmosphere of the classroom.
 
 With violent titles continuing to top the charts, gaming and learning have not always sat well together but the tide could be beginning to turn. Recent research by the London Institute of Education concluded that games have a valid place in the classroom. "Games teach life skills such as decision making, problem solving," said Martin Owen, at Futurelab. Mr Owen said games could also help children make quick assessments of situations and learning by trial and error.
 
 Futurelab is a non-profit organisation looking at ways of using technology for innovative learning. Most game firms are too busy turning a profit in the lucrative commercial market to consider developing games for use in schools but Liverpool-based games firm Lateral Visions saw a gap in the market. "Learning games were somewhat old-fashioned and we didn't see anyone else doing what we wanted to do," said Dr Carl Gavin, managing director of Lateral Visions. The company set out to write something that had all the look and feel of a commercial game but with an educational and learning element. The result is Racing Academy, a massively multiplayer car racing game, which requires not only a thirst for speed but a working knowledge of physics and engineering as well.
 
 It is being used by Futurelab to test the viability of using gaming in the classroom. "We are keen to find out whether alongside learning a game, we can also learn something that the rest of the world can understand as being educational," said Mr Owen. Players will have to understand how a car works in order to win races and the knowledge of physics and engineering that they gather along the way will be done in a way that no text book can teach. The game requires users to build and maintain their vehicles and to monitor and analyse performance using data from a variety of outputs, before and after racing. Teamwork is essential and a chat area allows students to exchange information and data, work collaboratively and review their own performances. This fusion of chatrooms and gaming is of special interest to Futurelab as it is through talking to others that much of the learning can be achieved, thinks Mr Owen.
 
 The game has been trialled in two secondary schools in Bristol and feedback from students has been positive. "Pupils used the statistics to work out the best way to build their cars and the online message board to share ideas and support each other," said Ben Williamson, a researcher at Futurelab charged with testing the game in real schools. Dr Gavin thinks the game satisfies both teachers' need for learning outcomes and the children's desire to rise to a challenge. "Games in the classroom need to support the teacher. It is not about giving children free rein to play game but recognising that games attract attention and offer a challenge," he said. Professor Angela MacFarlane, based at Bristol University, has spent several years researching how games can be incorporated into classrooms.
 
 Use of games in schools has been patchy she found, with Sim City proving the most popular. Traditionally schools have eschewed mainstream games in favour of used so-called edu-tainment software in a belief that such packages help to make learning fun, she found in her research. "It is perhaps in a compromise between edutainment and mainstream games that the greatest potential for classroom useable games lies," she wrote in a paper entitled Games and Learning. 'Lite' versions of existing games could be the way forward and would overcome one of the biggest hurdles - persuading developers to write for the educational market. This would appeal to developers because of the low costs involved in adapting them as well as offering a new opportunity for marketing. Already there are games on the market, such as Civilisation and Age of Empire, that have educational elements said Mr Owen. "Even in Grand Theft Auto it is not just the violence that engages people," he said. It could be some time until that particular game makes it into the classroom though.

tinydolphin:1.1b: A new trend in educational technology is being introduced by a company called Lateral Visions, which has created an innovative learning game called Racing Academy.
This racing game has been designed to not only entertain and inform students but also to teach them something useful about physics, engineering, and car mechanics.
The game was developed by a team at Futurelab in Liverpool, who believe that educational games can be much more than mere revenue streams for companies like Electronic Arts (EA).
They want to use these platforms to promote learning and to make education more interesting for students.
This approach has been successful with simulated reality gaming, which has been used extensively by educational institutions to create immersive experiences.
Lateral Visions, however, is taking this approach a step further by creating a massively multiplayer car racing game called Racing Academy.
The aim of this project is to use the popularity of the racing genre to engage students with an interactive experience that they can learn from and enjoy.
It's not just about winning, but also about understanding the principles behind the games.
The key feature of Racing Academy is its interactivity.
Users will have to build and maintain their cars using data from a variety of sources.
They can work together with others in chat rooms to help each other learn and improve.
The chatroom is a place where students can exchange information, discuss performance, and analyze their own stats.
In turn, this fusion of chat and gameplay will allow teachers to provide more focused learning experiences.
The success of Racing Academy could have far-reaching implications for the future of educational technology.
By using gaming as a tool to promote learning, it opens up new opportunities for innovative teaching methods and a range of subjects that students might not otherwise explore.
This is particularly exciting for students who may be passionate about cars but lack the skills or understanding to make informed decisions in a virtual world.
In terms of the potential impact on future education systems, this game could pave the way for more immersive and engaging learning experiences that are both fun and educational.
The development of games like Racing Academy by Lateral Visions suggests that the next generation of education gamers is about to explode onto the scene.

In a group of four schools in Bristol, they decided to test Racing Academy as part of their new educational strategy.
Each school has different teaching styles and resources.
School A is known for its hands-on approach, School B focuses on theoretical learning, School C uses technology extensively, and School D emphasizes teamwork and collaboration.
The test was conducted over a period of two months, with students from each school playing the game independently and reporting their experiences and findings to Futurelab.

At the end of the trial, the following observations were made:
1.
The students in School A learned more about Physics and Engineering than those in other schools.
Students in School B found teamwork to be a valuable skill while playing Racing Academy.
The students from School C focused mainly on understanding gaming technology.
While the students of School D had fun playing the game, they didn't learn any new skills.
The schools did not have similar teaching styles or resources that could explain the observations made.

Question: Based on these results and the following information about each school's teaching style and resources, which school(s) were likely to be using Gaming as an educational tool in their curriculum?

Analyze the observation for each school with respect to the teaching methodology: 
- School A has a hands-on approach.
Hence, it seems like they would benefit from the practical aspects of games.
Racing Academy, being a game requiring engineering and physics knowledge, will fit well with this teaching style.
- School B focuses on theoretical learning.
The teamwork aspect in Racing Academy makes sense for such educational institutions as it allows students to learn through collaboration rather than individual effort.
- School C uses technology extensively.
Given the tech-focused nature of Racing Academy, it's possible that they would benefit from this game.
- School D emphasizes teamwork and collaboration.
This aligns with Racing Academy where interaction is key.

Identify which of these schools were using games in their curriculum:
- Based on step 1, all four schools are potential candidates as the game's teaching methodology overlaps with each school's teaching style.
- However, since they have different resources and teaching styles, it's possible that each school is adapting the game in a way that suits its educational approach.
Answer: All four schools (School A, B, C, D) were likely to be using games as an educational tool in their curriculum based on Racing Academy.
The specific ways in which they incorporated the game into their teaching will vary due to their different resources and teaching styles.
